title: David Hobson (tenor)
text:
David Hobson (born 18 November 1960) is an Australian <a href="opera">opera</a> <a href="tenor">tenor</a> and composer.
Career.
Born in <a href="Ballarat">Ballarat</a>, Australia, Hobson sang with church and school choirs and local music groups as a child, but he was still vocally untrained when he performed as lead singer and bass guitarist with <a href="rock%20band">rock band</a>s while studying at the <a href="University%20of%20Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a>. However, despite the lack of a demonstration tape of "Macbeth" (see below) he was invited to join the <a href="Victoria%20State%20Opera">Victoria State Opera</a>, understudying the role of Frederic in the VSO's <a href="Joseph%20Papp">Joseph Papp</a> (Broadway) version of "<a href="The%20Pirates%20of%20Penzance">The Pirates of Penzance</a>" in 1986. This led to his becoming a member of the company's Young Artists Programme, and making his debut as Rodolfo in a Victorian country tour production of "<a href="La%20boh%C3%A8me">La bohème</a>" in 1987. In 1988 he made his debut with The Australian Opera (now <a href="Opera%20Australia">Opera Australia</a>) when he created the role of Lawrence in the world premiere of Brian Howard's opera "Whitsunday".
He is the <a href="composer">composer</a> of "Macbeth" (a 1985 music theatre piece), "Remembering Rosie" (2001 chamber opera), "The Loch Ard Suite" (for the 2002 light/sound installation "Shipwrecked" at <a href="Warrnambool">Warrnambool</a>) and the award-winning 2004 orchestral score for the Australian film "<a href="One%20Perfect%20Day%20%282004%20film%29">One Perfect Day</a>", as well as a number of songs including "Inside This Room" and the title song for "One Perfect Day".
In 1990, he reprised the role of Rodolfo, opposite <a href="Cheryl%20Barker">Cheryl Barker</a> as Mimì, in a new production of "La bohème" for The Australian Opera, directed by <a href="Baz%20Luhrmann">Baz Luhrmann</a>; this went on to become one of the company's most successful productions. It was filmed during its 1993 return season and broadcast on <a href="Australian%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">ABC TV</a> several times. Released on VHS in 1994, it was to become the first opera available on DVD (1998) and continues to be a best seller worldwide.
Hobson's <a href="Gilbert%20and%20Sullivan">Gilbert and Sullivan</a> roles with Opera Australia, include Nanki-Poo in "<a href="The%20Mikado">The Mikado</a>", Marco Palmieri in "<a href="The%20Gondoliers">The Gondoliers</a>", Ralph Rackstraw in "<a href="H.M.S.%20Pinafore">H.M.S. Pinafore</a>" and the Defendant in "<a href="Trial%20by%20Jury">Trial by Jury</a>".
Hobson returned to the role of Frederic in the record-breaking Opera Australia production of "<a href="The%20Pirates%20of%20Penzance">The Pirates of Penzance</a>" with seasons during 2006 in Sydney at the <a href="Sydney%20Opera%20House">Sydney Opera House</a>, in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a>, and in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a> at the Lyric Theatre, <a href="Queensland%20Performing%20Arts%20Centre">Queensland Performing Arts Centre</a>. The national tour continued in 2007, with seasons in <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> and <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, making a total of 100 performances in ten months.
His operatic repertoire extends from 17th century works to the present, Hobson's high lyric tenor voice (he is actually a rare "<a href="haute-contre">haute-contre</a>" or baroque tenor) is best suited to the <a href="baroque">baroque</a> and <a href="bel%20canto">bel canto</a> operas of the 18th and early 19th centuries, such as those composed by Mozart and Rossini. His <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Mozart</a> roles include Ferrando in "<a href="Cos%C3%AC%20fan%20tutte">Così fan tutte</a>", Don Ottavio in "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>", Tamino in "<a href="The%20Magic%20Flute">The Magic Flute</a>" and Belmonte in "<a href="Die%20Entf%C3%BChrung%20aus%20dem%20Serail">The Abduction from the Seraglio</a>". His <a href="Gioachino%20Rossini">Rossini</a> roles include Lindoro in "<a href="L%27italiana%20in%20Algeri">L'italiana in Algeri</a>", Ramiro in "<a href="La%20Cenerentola">La Cenerentola</a>", Count Almaviva in "<a href="The%20Barber%20of%20Seville">The Barber of Seville</a>", Dorvil in "<a href="La%20scala%20di%20seta">La scala di seta</a>" and Florville in "<a href="Il%20signor%20Bruschino">Il signor Bruschino</a>".
Many other roles have included Ernesto in Donizetti's "<a href="Don%20Pasquale">Don Pasquale</a>", Nadir in Bizet's "<a href="Les%20p%C3%AAcheurs%20de%20perles">The Pearl Fishers</a>", and a highly acclaimed Orphée in Gluck's "<a href="Orfeo%20ed%20Euridice">Orphée et Eurydice</a>", (the rarely performed 1774 Paris version for <a href="tenor">tenor</a>).
In 2008, he made his role debut as Nemorino in Donizetti's "<a href="L%27elisir%20d%27amore">L'elisir d'amore</a>" with the <a href="Victorian%20Opera%20%28Melbourne%29">Victorian Opera</a>, and created several roles in their world premiere season of "<a href="Through%20the%20Looking%20Glass%20%28opera%29">Through the Looking Glass</a>" by <a href="Alan%20John">Alan John</a>.
Hobson created the role of the Chevalier de Danceny in the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Opera">San Francisco Opera</a> world premiere of "<a href="The%20Dangerous%20Liaisons">The Dangerous Liaisons</a>" by <a href="Conrad%20Susa">Conrad Susa</a>, as well as the Architect in "<a href="The%20Eighth%20Wonder">The Eighth Wonder</a>" by <a href="Alan%20John">Alan John</a> and <a href="Michael%20Chamberlain">Michael Chamberlain</a> in "<a href="Lindy%20%28opera%29">Lindy</a>" by <a href="Moya%20Henderson">Moya Henderson</a> for Opera Australia.
In 2006, he sang the title role in a <a href="Perth%20International%20Arts%20Festival">Perth International Arts Festival</a> concert performance of "<a href="Candide%20%28operetta%29">Candide</a>" by <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a> and received rave reviews. Just weeks later he had the honour of singing before <a href="Elizabeth%20II">Elizabeth II</a> and many other distinguished guests, at a State Dinner in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a>.
Hobson is a much sought-after concert artist, frequently appearing in <a href="Musica%20Viva%20Australia">Musica Viva</a> recitals, and oratorios such as Handel's "<a href="Messiah%20%28Handel%29">Messiah</a>", and Mendelssohn's "<a href="Elijah%20%28oratorio%29">Elijah</a>", as well as opera galas, recitals and solo concerts, displaying both his extensive classical and lighter repertoires. Since 1991 he has been a regular performer at the outdoor Christmas concerts in either Sydney ("Carols in the Domain") or Melbourne ("<a href="Carols%20by%20Candlelight">Carols by Candlelight</a>") and, more recently, has appeared regularly in "Christmas at the House" at the Sydney Opera House. In February 2008 he made his debut at the <a href="Leeuwin%20Estate%20Concert%20Series">Leeuwin Estate Concert Series</a> in <a href="Margaret%20River%2C%20Western%20Australia">Margaret River</a> with Australian <a href="soprano">soprano</a> <a href="Yvonne%20Kenny">Yvonne Kenny</a>, and in March returned to <a href="Mildura">Mildura</a> with another regular partner, <a href="Marina%20Prior">Marina Prior</a>, to sing at the "Opera by the Lock". Working around his opera, recording and TV commitments, Hobson performed a series of concerts between April and September, appearing in Melbourne and regional Victoria and, marking the release of his CD, "A Little Closer", performed in two concerts in the Sydney Opera House Concert Hall in November.
Hobson and <a href="bass-baritone">bass-baritone</a> <a href="Teddy%20Tahu%20Rhodes">Teddy Tahu Rhodes</a>' CD "You'll Never Walk Alone" was released in February 2009, followed in March by an extensive Australian recital tour. One of the recitals was in <a href="Hobart">Hobart</a>, and a few weeks later Hobson returned for concerts with the <a href="Tasmanian%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra</a> in Hobart and <a href="Launceston%2C%20Tasmania">Launceston</a>.
Much of the second half of 2009 was occupied with touring for <a href="Musica%20Viva%20Australia">Musica Viva</a>, while December was devoted to another performance of Handel's "Messiah" with the <a href="Royal%20Melbourne%20Philharmonic">Royal Melbourne Philharmonic</a> at <a href="Melbourne%20Town%20Hall">Melbourne Town Hall</a>, a season of "Christmas at the House" in the Sydney Opera House Concert Hall, and an appearance at Melbourne's traditional Christmas Eve celebration "<a href="Carols%20by%20Candlelight">Carols by Candlelight</a>", at the <a href="Sidney%20Myer%20Music%20Bowl">Sidney Myer Music Bowl</a>, televised nationally.
Hobson's 2010 schedule began with a return to "Opera in the Alps" at <a href="Beechworth">Beechworth</a>, with <a href="Marina%20Prior">Marina Prior</a>, and continued with a reprise performance in the title role of "Candide" for the <a href="Sydney%20Festival">Sydney Festival</a> concert presentation of "Opera in the Domain" (both in January); another recital with Teddy Tahu Rhodes in Adelaide (March); and the principal role of Eisenstein – which he last performed in 2000 – in the Opera Australia production of the Johann Strauss II operetta "<a href="Die%20Fledermaus">Die Fledermaus</a>" at the <a href="State%20Theatre%20%28Melbourne%29">State Theatre</a>, <a href="Arts%20Centre%20Melbourne">Arts Centre Melbourne</a>, during May. April saw Hobson's debut as a specialist presenter on the new pay-TV <a href="STVDIO%20%28TV%20Channel%29">STVDIO</a> arts channel.
Hobson followed the "Fledermaus" season of traditional operetta with something completely different when he appeared at the <a href="Adelaide%20Cabaret%20Festival">Adelaide Cabaret Festival</a> in his stagework "Am I Really Here?" in June 2010 and a performance of <a href="Hans%20Zender">Zender</a>'s contemporary interpretation of <a href="Franz%20Schubert">Schubert</a>'s "<a href="Winterreise">Winterreise</a>" at the <a href="Brisbane%20Powerhouse">Brisbane Powerhouse</a> in July. The CD album "Singing for Love", a compilation of work by Hobson and Yvonne Kenny, was released in 2010 before their nationwide concert tour. A busy and varied year concluded with a series of concerts in four states, including three performances in Brisbane for the 25th anniversary season of "Spirit of Christmas" at <a href="Queensland%20Performing%20Arts%20Centre">QPAC</a> and a regulation appearance at Melbourne's "<a href="Carols%20by%20Candlelight">Carols by Candlelight</a>".
Hobson's 2011 schedule included a <a href="West%20Australian%20Opera">West Australian Opera</a> concert performance of "Die Fledermaus" in Perth; a flying visit to New Zealand in March; a third concert appearance with the Victoria Welsh Choir in June; his role debut as Count Danilo in <a href="Opera%20Australia">Opera Australia</a>'s new production of <a href="Franz%20Leh%C3%A1r">Lehár</a>'s "<a href="The%20Merry%20Widow">The Merry Widow</a>", followed immediately by another national concert tour with <a href="Teddy%20Tahu%20Rhodes">Teddy Tahu Rhodes</a> and performances of Handel's "Messiah" with the <a href="Sydney%20Philharmonia%20Choirs">Sydney Philharmonia Choirs</a> and Orchestra at the Sydney Opera House Concert Hall. There was another compilation CD, "The Best of David Hobson" and more solo concerts in several states.
In 2012 and 2013, Hobson appeared as <a href="Caractacus%20Pott">Caractacus Pott</a>s opposite <a href="Rachael%20Beck">Rachael Beck</a> as <a href="Truly%20Scrumptious">Truly Scrumptious</a> in an Australian touring production of the musical "<a href="Chitty%20Chitty%20Bang%20Bang%20%28musical%29">Chitty Chitty Bang Bang</a>".
The inaugural Australian cruise of the performing arts on the in November 2014 included Hobson as well as, among others, <a href="Cheryl%20Barker">Cheryl Barker</a>, <a href="Colin%20Lane">Colin Lane</a>, <a href="Teddy%20Tahu%20Rhodes">Teddy Tahu Rhodes</a>, <a href="Simon%20Tedeschi">Simon Tedeschi</a>, <a href="Elaine%20Paige">Elaine Paige</a>, <a href="Marina%20Prior">Marina Prior</a>, and <a href="Jonathon%20Welch">Jonathon Welch</a>. Hobson made his company debut for <a href="Opera%20Queensland">Opera Queensland</a> in a staged performance of Bernstein's "Candide" in 2015, directed by <a href="Lindy%20Hume">Lindy Hume</a>. Later that year, he joined Teddy Tahu Rhodes, <a href="Lisa%20McCune">Lisa McCune</a> and <a href="Greta%20Bradman">Greta Bradman</a> for a tour of the five Australian mainland state capitals and Auckland and Christchurch, New Zealand – where <a href="Jennifer%20Ward-Lealand">Jennifer Ward-Lealand</a> replaced McCune – From Broadway to La Scala.
Recordings.
Several of Hobson's operatic performances are available on DVD, and his CD albums include "Inside This Room" (a collaboration with <a href="David%20Hirschfelder">David Hirschfelder</a>), "Cinema Paradiso" (film songs), "Tenor and Baritone" (with <a href="Anthony%20Warlow">Anthony Warlow</a>), "The Exquisite Hour" (a collection of French art songs) and "The Promise" (his arrangements of an eclectic selection of songs from musicals, pop, etc., and two of his own compositions), which achieved Gold status within three weeks of release in November 2007. His 2008 album, "A Little Closer", covers classic pop songs and features two more of his compositions. His CD "Enchanted Way", featuring mainly Celtic folksongs of the British Isles, was released in 2010.
Private life.
Hobson's early life was spent in <a href="Ballarat">Ballarat</a> with parents Kathleen and Phil and siblings Anne, Jane, Ruth and Fiona.
He met his wife, <a href="ballerina">ballerina</a> Amber Simpson, when they performed together in 1992 in "<a href="L%27italiana%20in%20Algeri">L'italiana in Algeri</a>". They married in 1997. They have two children; daughter Madi (born 1998) and son Sam (born 2001).
Other activities.
Hobson was <a href="mentor">mentor</a> to model and TV host <a href="Erika%20Heynatz">Erika Heynatz</a> when they won the <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> reality singing show, "<a href="It%20Takes%20Two%20%28Australian%20TV%20series%29">It Takes Two</a>" in 2006, and returned in the 2007 season to partner celebrity <a href="Mimi%20Macpherson">Mimi Macpherson</a>. In late 2007 Hobson appeared in "<a href="Dancing%20with%20the%20Stars">Dancing with the Stars</a>" Series 7, with he and his mentor, Karina Schembri, finishing in third place. In 2008 he resumed his more familiar role of mentor to win "It Takes Two" Series 3, with <a href="Julia%20Morris">Julia Morris</a>.
In 2000, Hobson became the Inaugural Patron of the Ballarat Arts Foundation, and continues in that capacity.
At the end of March 2008, <a href="Musica%20Viva%20Australia">Musica Viva Australia</a> announced Hobson's appointment as the Musica Viva in Schools Ambassador for a programme to raise an awareness of the importance of music education in Australian schools.
In 2019, Hobson made a guest appearance on <a href="The%20Wiggles">The Wiggles</a>, performing a reworked version of <a href="Funicul%C3%AC%2C%20Funicul%C3%A0">Funiculì, Funiculà</a> alongside fellow Australian opera singer (and current Red Wiggle) Simon Pryce.
